results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movies: Reel 8]
results.brief_description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

In this film, Billy travels to the Russian cities of Leningrad and Moscow.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:04:00 some quick views the ‘Latvia’ passenger ship in sail
00:00:20:00 scenes in a European city including some construction sites
00:00:52:00 the domes of the St Petersburg Cathedral (also called Church of the resurrection of Christ or Church of the Saviour on Spilled Blood) in St Petersburg, Russia
00:02:21:00 looking at the St Petersburg Cathedral framed in the distance through snowy tree branches
00:02:40:00 Red Square in Moscow, Russia
00:03:39:00 St Basil’s Cathedral in Moscow, Russia
00:04:27:00 snow on people and traffic in Moscow
00:05:17:00 pedestrians and cars on the streets of Moscow
00:06:50:00 cars driving alongside a river in Moscow
00:07:05:00 a crowd watches a military parade of personal and armoured vehicles
00:09:03:00 snowy streets
00:09:49:00 airplane exhibition
00:10:27:00 people tobogganing in the snow amongst some trees
00:11:00:00 people take to their skis in a snowy forest

results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

In this film, Billy travels to Japan, Tahiti, New York and Funchal in Portugal. A feature of the film is a glimpse of what appears to be the Twin Towers of the World Trade Center in New York when under construction.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 a busy scene of junks sailing around a harbour, likely to be in Japan
00:00:30:00 for a large passenger ship being welcomed to port by a military band and Japanese geishas in costume
00:00:53:00 street scenes of a Japanese town, pagodas and historic buildings
00:01:43:00 a statue of an imposing looking man atop a rock formation
00:02:00:00 views of temples, traditional buildings and gardens
00:03:20:00 views of waterways, boats, ships, hills, some snow, and pagodas
00:06:20:00 view across the sea to some picturesque mountains in the background
00:07:37:00 some townhouses along the shoreline
00:08:01:00 a large passenger ship at a dock
00:08:38:00 the Stature of Liberty appears followed by the New York skyline
00:09:39:00 views of New York buildings including a glimpse of the Twin Towers of the World Trade Center during construction
00:09:55:00 a harbour view with ferries and piers and the Empire State Building in the background
00:11:20:00 a large tugboat chugs across the water
00:11:38:00 passengers on board a ship deck
00:13:28:00 Billy’s friends or relatives smile at the camera in a garden
00:14:29:00 a ship in port with some great cars of the era in the foreground
00:15:11:00 a public square and fountain, possibly in Portugal
00:16:26:00 decorative fishing boats being loaded in a port

results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movies: Reel 6]
results.brief_description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

In this film, Billy travels to England during 1962 to 1964. On his travel Billy films views of London, English coastlines and towns, including Blackpool, Brighton and Coventry. A feature of this film is the Coventry Cathedral which Billy filmed, possibly when it was being consecrated in 1962. The Cathedral is significant as, having been almost destroyed during a Luftwaffe attack on Coventry in 1940, it was rebuilt in a deliberate modern design alongside the remains in 1956 and came to symbolise peace and reconciliation. The design by architect Sir Basil Spence included many artworks such as ‘St Michael’s defeat of the Devil’ by Jacob Epstein which can be seen in Billy’s film.

00:00:16:00 London street scenes begin, including double decker buses, Big Ben clocktower and Grenadier Guards on horseback
00:01:35:00 St Paul’s Cathedral
00:01:52:00 views of the Thames River including London Bridge, pedestrian bridges, boats and the riverbanks
00:03:09:00 street views of London including the dome of St Paul’s Cathedral and a sign for the ‘Underground’ rail network
00:04:43:00 a large ferry
00:06:15:00 views around (most likely) the Royal Botanical Gardens Kew
00:07:12:00 spectators look at tulips in a public garden
00:07:45:00 views of an old church and cemetery
00:08:54:00 ‘Lady Godiva’ monument in Coventry, England
00:09:42:00 views around the Coventry Cathedral, including the artwork ‘St Michael’s defeat of the Devil’ on one of the Cathedral external walls
00:11:50:00 thatched houses
00:12:00:00 a very crowded beach scene
00:12:20:00 the Brighton Pavillon in Brighton, England
00:12:45:00 Arundel Castle in West Sussex, England
00:14:10:00 a carnival or street parade.
00:14:44:00 some lovely examples of trucks and buses of the era
00:15:25:00 views of English coastline and houses from a vessel at sea
00:15:32:00 a large ship and the ‘Liverpool Pilot’ vessel
00:15:45:00 an ‘Oyster and Prawn’ van in Blackpool, England
00:16:10:00 a look at a sandy populated beach from a higher vantage point
00:16:42:00 eating ice cream and cups of tea

results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

In this film, Billy travels to Macao, China and Hong Kong in the 1960s. The quality of the film can be challenging at times (shaky, sometimes dark and damaged) but it is well worth it for scenes of the busy waterways and street life around Hong Kong Island, Kowloon and Macau. Billy particularly focuses on the many different watercraft such as passenger and cargo ships, ferries, row boats, houseboats and plenty of wonderful traditional junks.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:46:00 scenes filmed from a train as it travels past cultivated fields, farmers, bullock teams, field hands
00:01:25:00 traditional house by as river
00:01:19:00 young children working on logs at a timber mill
00:02:12:00 field workers closer to the camera
00:02:30:00 small, covered junks on the water in a harbour
00:02:45:00 busy port
00:03:05:00 large group of moored, small house boats with mountains in the background
00:03:22:00 children playing on a beach
00:03:50:00 ferries and traditional sailing boats as well as large ships
00:04:29:00 large ferry
00:04:55:00 traditional junk sailing by a large modern ship
00:05:45:00 city residential apartment buildings with mountains in background.
00:06:18:00 city streets, shops and signs, including one for ‘Coca Cola’
00:08:07:00 new and old watercraft
00:08:75:00 colourful passenger ferry
00:08:35:00 lovely traditional junk in full sail
00:09:30:00 a child points at the camera while playing with friends
00:10:00:00 international shipping
00:10:30:00 wonderful striped canvas tent bathing boxes followed by scenes of locals relaxing at the beach.
00:12:52:00 another notable traditional junk sailing by the camera
00:14:11:00 vegetable sellers in low lying boats

Billy particularly focuses on the many different watercraft such as passenger and cargo ships, ferries, row boats, houseboats and plenty of wonderful traditional junks.

00:00:46:00 scenes filmed from a train as it travels past cultivated fields, farmers, bullock teams, field hands
00:01:25:00 traditional house by as river
00:01:19:00 young children working on logs at a timber mill
00:02:12:00 field workers closer to the camera
00:02:30:00 small, covered junks on the water in a harbour
00:02:45:00 busy port
00:03:05:00 large group of moored, small house boats with mountains in the background
00:03:22:00 children playing on a beach
00:03:50:00 ferries and traditional sailing boats as well as large ships
00:04:29:00 large ferry
00:04:55:00 traditional junk sailing by a large modern ship
00:05:45:00 city residential apartment buildings with mountains in background.
00:06:18:00 city streets, shops and signs, including one for ‘Coca Cola’
00:08:07:00 new and old watercraft
00:08:75:00 colourful passenger ferry
00:08:35:00 lovely traditional junk in full sail
00:09:30:00 a child points at the camera while playing with friends
00:10:00:00 international shipping
00:10:30:00 wonderful striped canvas tent bathing boxes followed by scenes of locals relaxing at the beach.
00:12:52:00 another notable traditional junk sailing by the camera
00:14:11:00 vegetable sellers in low lying boats

results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movies: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

In this film, Billy travels to the United States of America taking in the sights of Long Beach, Disneyland, San Francisco and San Diego all in California, USA.

00:02:10:00 a helicopter on the tarmac
00:02:45:00 views of some sailing yachts and piers

00:03:30:00 a particularly nice Hotel on a town or city corner
00:04:35:00 women with placards marching outside a ‘J C Penney’ store in San Diego

00:05:59:00 surf boards for hire on the beach

00:10:32:00 a rocket ship in Disneyland
00:11:05:00 Native American dancers performing for an audience in Disneyland

results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movies: Reel 13]
results.brief_description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

In this film, Billy travels to Taiping, Malaysia and Tarakan, Borneo and then journeys throughout Australia during 1961.

This film was originally made using standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

This film has a few scenes from Billy’s travels to Taiping in Malaysia before moving on to Sydney and Melbourne. Billy includes some lovely scenes of being at sea, ships and shipping. The scenes in Sydney include the Harbour, the Bridge and some busy streets. In Melbourne we see the Moomba Parade, trams and vintage cars along St Kilda Road, the Yarra River and the Robin Boyd Sculpture at Southbank.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:06:00 on board ship
00:00:33:00 two passengers disembarking in Malaysia
00:00:43:00 views of traditional Malaysian housing
00:00:55:00 people cycling along roads in Taiping, Malaysia
00:01:09:00 women standing with local children in Taiping, all smiling at the camera
00:01:20:00 a woman walking toward embarkation area for a ship
00:02:12:00 great shot of a passenger ship speeding along through the water
00:03:45:00 (possibly) Pulau Pising Lighthouse on Banana Island in the Malacca Straits.
00:04:58:00 a glimpse of some passengers on board ship as they lean over the rail coming into Sydney Harbour.
00:05:43:00 a large liner at berth
00:06:10:00 military ship in Sydney Harbour
00:06:40:00 travelling over the Harbour Bridge by car
00:07:23:00 yachts on the Harbour
00:08:43:00 sign for ‘Wollongong’ followed by an early model Holden (EK)
00:12:13:00 Robin Boyd Sculpture at Southgate, Melbourne, followed by the Yarra River, river boats and Princes Bridge.
00:12:54:00 Circa 1960s (and earlier) cars and trams on St Kilda Road in Melbourne
00:13:13:00 Moomba Parade in Melbourne
00:13:39:00 a decorated ‘A.L.P’ (Australian Labor Party) parade float
00:13:43:00 the ‘Magga Dan Esberg’ ship at a berth.
00:16:50:00 Anzac Day Parade.

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 24]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia’. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures a group walking trip by members of the ‘Walkabouters’ club to the Grampians (Gariwerd) in Victoria. It features the making of a ‘pit oven’ style barbeque and showcases the walking to be had by visitors through the many ravines and paths but also the grandeur of the sweeping views from what can seem like perilous pinnacles and lookouts.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title cards ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘The Dreaming Place’, ‘A WHC Film’
00:00:38:00 views of the Grampians range off in the distance
00:00:56:00 driving through a small township
00:02:51:00 creating a ‘pit oven’ by setting a fire in a deep hole in the ground
00:02:59:00 stones are thrown into the flames and then covered with pieces of terracotta tiles on which meat in aluminium foil is placed for cooking
00:03:38:00 the pit is covered with a piece of metal, hessian bags, stones and dirt
00:04:15:00 a woman climber is helped to the top of some rocks
00:06:10:00 cars driving along a dirt road in the bush
00:06:44:00 an example of the the beautiful rock of the Grampians
00:07:07:00 sign for ‘Forest Commision of Victoria’ ‘Camp of the Emu’s Foot’
00:07:15:00 Indigenous art on rock walls
00:09:48:00 a still river which runs under a wooden walk bridge among tall reeds
00:10:19:00 a fenced off shallow cavern possibly with Indigenous drawings on the rock
00:10:35:00 views of Indigenous drawings up close
00:11:07:00 driving through the bush
00:11:54:00 grey patchy granite rock of the Grampians
00:12:29:00 a lone walker stands on top of a high peak
00:15:25:00 walking through the bush
00:17:00:00 groups of kangaroos and emus
00:18:23:00 climbing a steep ravine
00:20:19:00 sitting on a precipice overlooking the dramatic scenery below
00:20:43:00 a large body of water, possibly Lake Fyans in the Grampians
00:23:22:00 walking along narrow pathways through the bush
00:24:14:00 sign ‘Grand Canyon’
00:25:43:00 sign ‘Echo Cave’ which appears to be painted on the rock itself
00:26:13:00 another sign ‘Pinnacle Street’ painted on a path rock
00:26:24:00 a rock worn away into the shape of a mushroom
00:26:49:00 sign ‘Silent Street’
00:28:12:00 walkers at a pinnacle lookout showing the fencing used for safety in the Grampians

results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movies: Reel 12]
results.brief_description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

This film contains scenes of Billy’s travels on the steamship Southern Cross, in 1960 which travelled between Australia and Europe. It is a little difficult to locate exactly where Billy visits but we can definitely see scenes of England, the Netherlands and Greece. The SS Southern Cross was a modern passenger ship built in 1955 to an innovative design which catered specifically for the tourist trade, starting a trend of ‘aft-engined’ ships, leaving more space for passengers and their needs. The Southern Cross was also the first major liner to have no cargo space, other than for ship’s stores and passenger luggage.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:03:00 views of a shoreline and sea
00:01:14:00 a large ship or ferry being loaded at the dock
00:01:48:00 a large and busy tugboat
00:01:50:00 passengers playing tennis on the deck of a ship
00:02:30:00 South Africa Airways airplane on the tarmac
00:03:15:00 a large fountain in a town setting
00:03:49:00 mountain views followed by a picturesque river flowing through hills
00:04:23:00 passengers travelling from a ship, in what appears to be a large lifeboat, to shore
00:04:51:00 views of a large military memorial in a public square setting.
00:04:58:00 dancers in traditional costume give an exhibition of Greek folk dancing to passengers on board a ship.
00:06:19:00 town houses and buildings overlooking houseboats moored on the banks of a canal, with a sign for Grachten (canal)
00:06:58:00 tramcar in a town
00:07:14:00 a large and crowded beach
00:07:36:00 street scenes
00:08:15:00 keen swimmers in a canal or river
00:08:24:00 a glimpse of a windmill
00:08:50:00 boats, ferries and yachts in a bay
00:09:30:00 a passenger ship arrives at a dock
00:10:54:00 scenes of lovely hills and farmlands, thatched cottages and beaches
00:12:15:00 a ‘Punch and Judy’ tent indicates that Billy is in England
00:14:50:00 a plane is filmed overhead
00:15:15:00 a Greek ‘Evezone’ presidential guard dressed in traditional costume
00:16:16:00 a spectacular view of mountain seen at the end of a street, behind shops and buildings, probably in Greece

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 23]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film captures the scenery around the You Yangs and other nature spots in Victoria. Wallace includes lots of close-ups of wildflowers along the way as well as old farm machinery, some lovely old buildings, monuments, rocky outcrops, scrub, trees and sky.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:02:35:00 walkers in the scrub
00:03:22:00 a koala peers at the camera
00:03:36:00 remains of a wooden sluice in a creek that may have been an old gold mining site
00:03:50:00 hearing instructions or a talk at a campsite with a fire
00:04:45:00 setting off on a walk through farm lands and gates
00:05:05:00 sheep run across a paddock and a swirling, foaming river spilling across rocks with spectacular waterfalls
00:06:52:00 collecting driftwood by the dramatic river
00:07:18:00 scenes showing the treacherous route for walking the banks of the swollen, fast flowing river
00:09:54:00 jumping from rock to rock over a creek
00:10:18:00 using logs to cross a creek
00:10:27:00 hikers walk up a long grassy hill with some sheep running by, toward a gravel quarry or storage area
00:11:03:00 looking for rock specimens or stones in the gravel
00:11:13:00 some hikers stop for a chat before scrambling over a rocky part of the hills
00:12:15:00 flowers, mushrooms and toadstools
00:13:08:00 a long lizard close-up followed by a centipede
00:14:40:00 a trickling creek before scenes of rushing waters in a small creek
00:15:50:00 country roads
00:16:29:00 filming a photographer taking pictures of wildflowers followed by close-ups of flowers
00:18:16:00 several wild orchids
00:19:15:00 a campfire at night
00:19:44:00 stone monument with a plaque that reads ‘Erected 1951. In memory of the pioneers of Steiglitz and the discovery of gold 1851 - 1853’
00:19:50:00 the the lovely brick Steiglitz Court House among gumtrees, a plain but lovely old house across the road and a farm cottage next to an old chimney that could be all that remains of an earlier house
00:20:33:00 a flock of ducks or geese
00:20:45:00 an old brick fireplace surrounded by the trees and bushes that have overtaken it, followed by several ageing weatherboard buildings
00:21:23:00 sign ‘Walking track to Flinders Peak’ (in the You Yangs, Victoria) followed by views from a higher vantage point in the You Yangs
00:22:19:00 views of jutting rocks and outcrops and some of the farmland beyond the You Yangs
00:23:48:00 plaque for ‘Matthew Flinders RN who stood on this rock to survey the bay’
